Comment Head: Spoiler Film Review: The Shawshank Redemption
Comment Body: Film Review: The Shawshank Redemption This drama set in the year of 1940's involves a banker by the name of Andy Dufresne, as played by Tim Robbins, being jailed for the crime of murdering his wife and her lover. This screen play was written as well as directed by Frank Darabont and was produced by Niki Marvin. The film itself is based on the novel Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption by Stephen King. The Prison Warden, Samuel Norton, as played by Bob Gunton employs the aid of Andy for many financial endeavors and The voiceover in the film was provided by Ellis Redding, also known as Red, as played by Morgan Freeman and Brooks Hatlen, as played by James Whitmore.  The plot involves Andy enduring heinous acts of torture in prison while serving 2 life sentences all for a crime that only he knows he did not commit. Gaining the trust and kinship of Red allows Andy to adapt to prison life. The theme throughout the movie involves the motion of hope. Although the prison life does not offer any thoughts of freedom behind bars, the thoughts of hope keep many prisoners sane throughout the duration of time they must spend while locked away.  Many of the motif's throughout the film included hope, power, freedom, fear, persistence, rehabilitation, and salvation. An example of hope included Andy playing opera music for all of the prison to hear. Although the music was not long lived, the music served as a sign of hope not only for Andy, but the entire lot of prisoners as well. An example of power included the scene when Andy was almost tossed off of the roof top of a building by a guard. Although the audience may see Andy as helpless, he also holds a particular amount of power by telling the guard about information not previously known, thus, giving Andy power over his own life. An example of freedom within the film comes from the moment Red takes out a hammer in which he tells the viewer about tunneling out of the prison. Fear immediately begins for Andy when the judge sentences him to 2 life sentences and many particularly bad encounters with other prison members. Persistence is found when Andy's drive to fight off other prisoners never ends, but instead continues to fight them off each time they approach. Rehabilitation within the film is demonstrated within the prison itself. The main purpose of the prison is to rehabilitate the prisoners so that they can properly function within society once they are released, examples of this include the classes that are introduced, Andy teaching other prisoners basic skill sets, and the use of the library. The idea of salvation is generally current within the film as well. The bible is quoted throughout the film and used to remind Andy of freedom and safety.Sound effects, dialogue, and musical score were used to create the make-up of the soundtrack. Sounds from action off screen allowed the viewers imagination to fill in what happened in the surrounding environment. Ironic counterpoint was used within the film several times, but the first being when the musical score involved pleasantry and up-tempo beats while Andy was actually in moral dilemma from his wife leaving him for the man she was cheating on him with. Fade out was also used to depict different places within the prison at the same time action was occurring. The emotional effect/ mood is created by the effects, dialogue, and musical score. The characters actions within the film, along with rhythmic elements that match visual elements help to create a smooth and concise transition from scene to scene. The style/ texture of the film involves a color palette that is designed to communicate aspects of character placement, setting, and story to the viewer. For example, the clothing wore within the film by the prisoners was not colorful, but instead demonstrated that of individuals that do not have much say within their environment. On the other hand, the guards of the prison wear sharp, brightly colored uniforms that demonstrate their dominance over structure within the prison. Although thoughts of prison life may be discouraging, the movie attempts to elevate the theme for hope throughout.

Comment Head: An inspiring showpiece of defiance and perseverence
Comment Body: This is truly an inspiring film. Andy's defiance and perseverance in the face of injustice and abuse gives the film its dark and rich flavor. Buckle up and grab some nachos, you're in for a hell of a ride!

Shawshank Redemption is a film about the unlikely friendship between two men from different walks of life. Their paths would not have even crossed had Andy, portrayed by Tim Robbins, not been falsely imprisoned for the murder of his wife and her lover. Andy becomes friends with Red, played by Morgan Freeman; a prison bootlegger who was guilty of his crime of murder. This unlikely friendship becomes their saving grace. Their friendship makes their prison days more bearable until Andy's escape changes things. Red must serve his remaining sentence with memories of their time together. Andy left clues for Red to find him so they could be reunited.When Andy first arrives at the prison, Red and fellow inmates make bets on which new guy will break down first. Red chooses Andy on first sight. What a culture shock Andy and the new prisoners receive before they ever enter the cell block. We see them get verbally abused, stripped of their rights, showered with hoses, deloused, and made to march naked to their new homes. This stark transition makes the audience feel sympathy and humiliation for these men. When the first man breaks down that night, we see him get badly beaten by the guards. We find out in the morning that he didn't receive medical attention and died from the beating. Shawshank Redemption is one of those movies where you can help but root for the underdog. While we are unsure if Andy committed the crime he was sentenced for or not, you can't help but root for the guy. When it's revealed later on that he is not guilty, it makes you root for him even more. He had his chance to get out of prison as a free man but the warden eliminated that opportunity. The only way Andy was able to leave that prison was on his own terms. Set in 1947, Shawshank Redemption stays true to its timeframe. There are not any special effects or elaborate film techniques that wouldn't have been seen during this time. At no time is the story overshadowed by theatrics or surroundings. The lighting and sound effects appear as natural as if watching it all from across a room. The small details are what make this movie so believable. Shawshank Redemption can be compared to The Green Mile. Another film set in a 1930's prison. Both movies force the audience to look beyond the crimes the men have been convicted of and look at the man himself. Both movies have strong actors and strong supporting roles. Both movies are made with careful detail allowing the story to take center stage. While there are many prison movies out there to choose from, Shawshank Redemption tops the list. What makes this movie great is that it's not about the escape but it's about the relationships formed leading up to the escape. The real treat is seeing these friends reunited against all odds later in life.

Shawshank Redemption is a very moving story about hope and the power of friendship. The cast is first rate with everyone giving a great performance. Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman carry the movie, but Bob Gunton and Clancy Brown are perfect as the Warden Norton and prison guard captain Hadley respectively. And James Whitmore's portrayal of an elderly inmate Brooks is moving. The screenplay gives almost every actor at least one or more memorable lines through out the film. As well as a very surprising "twist" near the end that almost knocked me out of my chair. If you have not seen this movie rent it or better yet buy it. As I bet you'll want to see this one more than once.

this is the best movie i seen till yet One of the greatest of all war films, Klimov's stunning work stands amongst such works in which the horror and sorrow of conflict are made fresh over again for the viewer, left to stumble numb from the cinema thereafter. Produced for the 40th anniversary of Russia's triumph over the German invaders in WW2, based upon a novella by a writer who was a teenage partisan during the war, the propagandist use to which it was later put - when the GDR was still in the Eastern Bloc, citizens were forced to watch this to warn them of another rise of fascism - does not impair its effect today at all. It echoes intensity found in another masterpiece by the director. Klimov's shorter Larissa (1980) is a remorseful elegy to his late wife. Poetic and very personal, its sense of shock anticipates the heightened anguish that ultimately reverberates through Come And See. Through his images, the director stares uncomprehendingly at a world where lives are removed cruelly and without reason, if on this occasion not just one, but thousands.

Comment Head: Best movie I have ever seen
Comment Body: This movie contains a lot of important topics that really matters to my practical life. actually this one is my favorite I wish I could meet the producer of the Film .... The story begins with the trial of a young banker, Andy Dufrense, victimized by circumstantial evidence, resulting in a conviction for the murder of his wife and her lover. After a quick conviction, Andy finds himself serving a life sentence at Shawshank prison, with no hope of parole. He exists in this prison only in appearance, keeping his mind free from the drab walls around him. His ability to do this results in the gaining of respect from his fellow inmates, but most of all from Ellis Redding. Ellis, commonly referred to as Red, finds gainful use of his entrepreneurial spirit within the drab walls of Shawshank by dealing in contraband and commodities rare to the confines of prison. Andy's demeanor and undeniable sense of hope causes Red to take a deeper look at himself, and the world around him. Andy proves to Red and the other inmates that in the conventional walls of Shawshank prison convention will find no home in his lifestyle.

Comment Head: Wonderfully crafted motion picture with wide appeal
Comment Body: THIS is what movies are all about! A magnificent story, first-class actors, a superbly talented director, plus all the necessary attendant and supporting talents including set design, lighting, music, scripting, and all else that is required in the mix to create a masterpiece. Not a moment of the film is wasted, no segment too short or too long: it is all "just right". Who would have thought that a story about men in a cruel prison system could be developed into a memorable movie with many marvellous messages. May I single out one of my favourite actors, James Whitmore? I cannot imagine anyone else more suited to the role than he. In fact, the casting in this epic is remarkable: all parts ideally filled with class actors. Morgan Freeman, on the other hand, is not one of my screen favourites, but it's impossible to find any fault with him, and somehow he puts his mark on the role and makes it his. Tim Robbins is perfect; each time I see this film, I appreciate his acting more and more. It's so easy to give Shawshank Redemption a TEN. Surely anything less would be an injustice? Yes, Virginia, there IS a Santa Claus !

Comment Head: Is this the best movie of all time? - it is not
Comment Body: Won't say to much about this movie, it's a good one. It has an interesting theme (but not new or reinterpreted), a nice effort in describing the characters and their transformation, yes. Some bits of good soundtrack, yes. and OK climax and overall an entertaining feature-film, yes. But how in a million years can be this the greatest MOVIE of all time? PleasePlease

This is a good movie, but I'm surprised to see that it's got the #1 spot on IMDb's top movie list. The acting is excellent, and it has a great message; however, it's lacking a big "wow" moment for me. A lot of things that happened weren't necessarily "predictable", but I also wasn't shocked either. Still, it's a good movie that everyone should see.

Although the film is set in Maine, the Ohio State Reformatory in Mansfield, Ohio stood in for Shawshank Prison. The structure was slated to be torn down, but the production delayed its demolition for a year. After the film wrapped, all the buildings in the complex were torn down except the cell block and main administrative building, which were preserved for historical purposes.That's why I give it a 9, not a 10.Just joking. I'd give it a 9 any old day. I never give 10s.

This film wasn't that successful when it was released. Over the years since then, it's become regarded by many people as one of the best films ever made. It's an above-average prison film that's well-acted - but it's nothing special. It's slow and too long. Many fans of this film claim that it's a feel-good film - an uplifting story about friendship and mental strength. Some even claim that watching it can cure depressed viewers. However, it's a heavy-going film that includes beatings and rape.We never find out whether or not the protagonist committed the double murder that he's imprisoned for, which is a crucial point as a viewer. If he's innocent, then we should be on his side and want him to escape; if he's guilty, then he's not a sympathetic character.

This is a fantastic film but I don't think it deserves the top spot on the site. I would argue that The Godfather or even Citizen Kane is better. The first time I viewed Shawshank Redemption I didn't find it to be anything special. Sure, stars Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman were good BUT their performances weren't anything special...or so I thought at the time.Frank Darabont directs Shawshank Redemption with a gentle, guiding hand allowing the actors to discover the essence within their characters. Some actors, undoubtedly, would not be up to the task. Robbins and Freeman, however, are not "some actors." They are consummate actors and masterful in their portrayals here.Based upon Stephen King's novella, Darabont creates a film that never buys into the drama of its story, instead choosing to present the lives of the characters involved without histrionics. I have long felt, in fact, that the film may even improve upon the novella by bringing it into focus and providing it with a pacing that allows a more explicit character development.I have noticed that many of my favorite films are ensemble pieces, and while Robbins and Freeman shine here it is actually the entire cast that brings this story to life with such grace and beauty. Supporting performances by the likes of James Whitmore, William Sadler, Gil Bellows and others who take what could be caricatures and give them in-depth personalities and thoughts and feelings.Thomas Newman's score is supremely divine and changes along with the characters. It further enhances Darabont's pacing, as well. There are so many memorable scenes in Shawshank Redemption, however, the closing scene is certainly among one of the best closing scenes ever witnessed.It is hard to fathom that a "prison" movie could be a source of tremendous hope, light and inspiration. Yet, to call Shawshank Redemption a prison movie is to minimize its greatness. It is a brilliant film, a study of humanity in all its wonder AND it happens to take place within the confines of a prison.Moving, brilliant, inspirational, hopeful and empowering are all words that describe "The Shawshank Redemption." With outstanding performances from its ensemble cast and a work of tremendous cinematic poetry by director Frank Darabont. "Shawshank Redemption" creates a stellar vision that teaches, challenges, inspires and evokes a wide array of emotions and thoughts that serves to remind us that in the darkest moments of our lives there is always a light that shines within.

This is my favorite movie i have ever seen in my life. I really love watching this magnificent film over and over. Morgan Freeman and Tim Robins acted the main role which was extremely immersive. I think there are several sections and parts during the story which were also appeared in a great TV series, in Prison Break. It is not a coincidence that this is the best ranked movie ever on the IMDb's list. It is a pleasure watching for every age group because it's humor, for lovely characters and actors, for it's imagery and for the feeling of a dramatic ending. Beside Andy Dufresne's escape and his persistent way out of the prison, my favorite person was James Whitmore (rip) who was the kindest and loveliest man from all the prisoners. I was really sad when he died not only in the film but also in life. Finally, i can only say that this film is far, far away the most beautiful film in my movie-history, it is honor to be the top rated one.

if u don't see this one then you have not seen anything The Shawshank Redemption" is a movie about time, patience and loyalty -- not sexy qualities, perhaps, but they grow on you during the subterranean progress of this story, which is about how two men serving life sentences in prison become The partnership between the characters played by Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman is crucial to the way the story unfolds. This is not a "prison drama" in any conventional sense of the word. It is not about violence, riots or melodrama. The word "redemption" is in the title for a reason. The movie is based on a story, Rita Hayworth and the Shawshank Redemption, by Stephen King, which is quite unlike most of King's work. The horror here is not of the supernatural kind, but of the sort that flows from the realization than 10, 20, 30 years of a man's life have unreeled in the same unchanging daily prison routine. friends and find a way to fight off despair.

The Shawshank Redemption is undoubtedly deserves to be the highest rated movie. I watched this movie for the umpteenth time. A movie I would never ever get bored of. Written & directed by Frank Darabont, this prison drama is a simple but profoundly moving tale of hope, friendship & redemption. Cinematography exquisitely captures the monotonous daily life inside prison. The bond that grows between the two main characters is unforgettable and the score is the best I have heard. Morgan Freeman makes us feel the sadness and Tim Robbins, the faith. The more times you watch it, the more you love it, and the more you learn from it Whatever you do, don't listen to the people who say this movie is overrated because this is one of the most inspiring and greatest movies ever. It has everything you could possibly want in a movie. If you don't love Shawshank, chances are you are beyond redemption. It is hard to find a more proper word for the film than a masterpiece. It's in my top five movies of all time.

Phillip Fawcett piano teacher says this is the greatest redemption movie of them all. And I should know, since the music world was a life I'm only too delighted to be out of. Strictly speaking, Shawshank is not 'redemption', because after all what did the guy need redeeming 'from'? He was innocent. It is basically a giant metaphor for a journey from an entrapped and miserable existence to a beautiful promised land. It is set as a prison story, but really symbolizes any arena of life where one may feel hopeless and desperate to get out of a seemingly impossible situation.Beautifully written with a host of engaging characters, where for once the good are equally as interesting as the bad. I always find it curious that in many prison dramas when the guards, especially the warden, are the bad guys whereas the inmates (criminals, we assume) are the good. At least the protagonists are. Take Escape from Alcatraz as another example. I wonder what this says about our society and the concept of good and evil we have deep down? I believe it's a closet hatred of authority in general. A fear of the state, perhaps. With good reason.

Comment Head: One of the best of all time.
Comment Body: This movie has all of the best Hollywood has to offer from A-list actors to stunning scenery to a dialogue that will not leave you wanting. It delves into the mind and soul in ways you probably can't imagine. the plot seems believable as do the characters portrayed. If you have a soul, you will laugh, cry, get angry, be pleased and relieved. Andy is a character you will love and the prison workers you will hate. You really do get the whole gamut of emotions in this one. I have seen this one as many times as any other movie I've ever seen and I never get tired of it. My wife and I can sit down with this one several times a year and love it the same every time. You will love it!!

Comment Head: Tied for my favorite movie of all time.
Comment Body: This ranks among my favorite movies of all time. I'd say it's tied for first place. The ending is perhaps the most satisfying ending to a movie that I've ever seen. It's not necessarily the type of movie you watch over and over, yet I have watched it several times and it's engaging entertainment each time I watch. In fact, I would say that this movie goes beyond the pure entertainment category. It's a story that is truly inspiring. Morgan Freeman's character, Red, delivers a voice-over towards the end about hope that is perhaps the best voice-over in cinema history. I know I'm laying it on thick, but I truly love this movie. There are certainly scenes that are hard to watch, as Tim Robbins character goes through many trials while incarcerated, but the way he makes it through them is quite amazing. I was surprised to learn that this is based on a piece of fiction by Stephen King, but the more I learn about him, the more I see that he writes a lot more than just horror novels. I hope to read the book one day, as I'd bet it is quite good. Every aspect of this movie is pure perfection: directing, acting, editing, soundtrack... the list goes on. It has a permanent place in my movie collection and it also should in yours.

I recently watched The Shawshank Redemption, and what stuck out to me most was the offer of hope that Andy Dufresne offers to the inmates at Shawshank. The prison is depicted to be a place where people are treated poorly, abused, assaulted in every form and through it all dehumanized completely. We see this through the life of Brooks, who lost all hope of a good and normal life in the world that he became happy in Shawshank, identifying with being a crock and only a crock there. Once he is released from prison, he contemplates what is the best way to get back in, so that he can go home. Instead, he kills himself, because he would rather die than be a free man outside of the prison walls. But, when a innocent man walks into the prison and offers hope to the inmates, lives are changed. Although all of the inmates claim to be "innocent,"Andy was the only true innocent man in the prison, and with that he stuck out in every way. Andy reminds them that "hope is a good thing, maybe the best of things, and no good thing ever dies." Jesus Christ was the only truly innocent man to ever walk this Earth. Similarly, God has told us through his words that are bodies are tarnished by the worlds sin and evil. We are in a world run by our fleshly desires and sin. But, Jesus, as perfect as He is, stepped into our evil world and offered us Hope. He continues to save change lives today, many more than Andy Dufresne. Shawshank Redemption is a great feel-good, while still heart wrenching movie, but it has much more to offer than just a 2.5 hour movie. Next time you watch it, think about the life Andy is living and the example he is portraying for the other inmates, and consider the true life that Jesus Christ is trying to offer to you.

*** This review may contain spoilers ***I believe that this film is the best story ever told on film, and I'm about to tell you why.Tim Robbins plays Andy Dufresne, a city banker, wrongfully convicted of murdering his wife and her lover. He is sent to Shawshank Prison in 1947 and receives a double life sentence for the crime. Andy forms an unlikely friendship with "Red" (Morgan Freeman), the man who knows how to get things. Andy faces many trials in prison, but forms an alliance with the wardens because he is able to use his banking experience to help the corrupt officials amass personal fortunes. The story unfolds....I was so impressed with how every single subplot was given a great deal of respect and attention from the director. The acting was world-class. I have never seen Tim Robbins act as well since, Morgan Freeman maybe (e.g. Seven). The twists were unexpected, an although this film had a familiar feel, it wasn't even slightly pretentious, it was original. The cinematography was grand and expressive. It gave a real impression of the sheer magnitude of this daunting prison.But the one thing which makes THE SHAWSHANK REDEMPTION stand above all other films, is the attention given to the story. The film depends on the story and the way in which it unravels. It's a powerful, poignant, thought-provoking, challenging film like no other. If Andy were to comment on this film, I think he might say: "Get busy watching, or get busy dying." Take his advice.Thoroughly recommended.

Comment Head: Lots of questions some comments, and la dash of praise
Comment Body: I'm not sure that I would crawl through a pile of crap for my freedom, just saying. How did the poster get back into place? What happens to them after they have found their freedom? Do they enjoy it? Do they go back to their old ways of doing things? What kind of life do they lead?--that being said, how much time is left for them on this earth? If they believe in redemption, do they believe in an afterlife? What do they do with their money? What do they spend it on? Do they buy new clothes? Did they not have what they needed in jail? Were they not given three meals a day, a cot, a toilet. Perhaps their life was too simple and they wanted to make it more complicated. Perhaps they had grown bored with their lives and were looking for excitement. That being said, I must feel really freaking desperate, really output to crawl through a sewer, and perhaps they feel this way after being locked up for a long time. So yes, this man is brace. It seems they have change. I enjoyed watching this movie; I believe the actors played their parts well. Well-done

Freeman as "Red" is the jail-wise con that repeatedly is turned away by the system. A must watch.

Best movie. From the ingenious opening credits to the subversive ending, Deadpool constantly upends and tropes you're used to seeing in superhero flicks in the past few years. What's great here is the filmmakers had something weird and perverse and just went with it. Jokes about pedophilia, pegging, and sex run rampant, but it's never really dark, despite the mature subject matter. On top of that, it's also very refreshing to see a superhero in such a big studio film. It's unheard of these days. Fox and other studios, learn from this success. It's not the fact that a hard R-rated film can do well, it's that Deadpool also happens to be very good, most likely because you, Fox, actually gave the filmmakers the creative freedom to do whatever the hell they wanted.

Comment Head: This is the highest rated movie on IMDb?
Comment Body: Why? This is why we can't have nice things and why IMDb ratings are a joke. The Godfather and The Godfather Part II are better movies. 12 Angry Men is my favorite movie and it is a much better movie. The Third Man is better. Citizen Kane is better. Fight Club is a better movie. Judgment at Nuremberg is a better film. One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is better. Seven Samurai is a better movie and it is in Japanese. Das Boot is better. It is in German. M is better--and it is in German. Goodfellas is better. Platoon is a better movie. Touch of Evil is a better film. Spotlight is better. There Will Be Blood is better. Chinatown is better. Ran is a better movie. It is in Japanese. All About Eve is better. Up is better. To Kill a Mockingbird is better. Am√©lie is a better film--and it is in French. I could easily name two score other movies that are better than the highly overrated "The Shawshank Redemption."Pathetic.

This is the best movie i've watched so far till now. The Shawshank Redemption is without a doubt one of the most brilliant movies I have ever seen. Similar to The Green Mile in many respects (and better than it in almost all of them), these two movies have shown us that Stephen King is a master not only of horror but also of prose that shakes the soul and moves the heart. The plot is average, but King did great things with it in his novella that are only furthered by the direction, and the acting is so top-rate it's almost scary.Tim Robbins plays Andy Dufrane, wrongly imprisoned for 20 years for the murder of his wife. The story focuses on Andy's relationship with "Red" Redding (Morgan Freeman, in probably his best role) and his attempts to escape from Shawshank. Bob Gunton is positively evil and frightening as Warden Norton, and there are great performances and cameos all around; the most prominent one being Gil Bellows (late as Billy of Ally McBeal) as Tommy, a fellow inmate of Andy's who suffers under the iron will of Norton.If you haven't seen this movie, GO AND RENT IT NOW. You will not be disappointed. It is positively the best movie of the '90's, and one of my Top 3 of all time. This movie is a spectacle to move the mind, soul, and heart. 10/10

One of my favorite movies. It's a must see movie in my opinion. Seriously one of my all time favorites. Shawshank Redemption is a very moving story about hope and the power of friendship. The cast is first rate with everyone giving a great performance. Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman carry the movie, but Bob Gunton and Clancy Brown are perfect as the Warden Norton and prison guard captain Hadley respectively. And James Whitmore's portrayal of an elderly inmate Brooks is moving. The screenplay gives almost every actor at least one or more memorable lines through out the film. As well as a very surprising "twist" near the end that almost knocked me out of my chair. If you have not seen this movie rent it or better yet buy it. As I bet you'll want to see this one more than once.

I have watched this title multiple times not just for its motivational value which is top notch but also for its dialogues. Despite the pace of the movie, It doesn't bore you at any point. It doesn't matter whether the protagonist gets redemption or not. His character shows utmost patient positivism towards life which is what many of lose at one moment or the other.Both lead actors have played their roles well. In certain parts, I wasn't comfortable with the main protagonist being too perfect playing the situation around him like a violin. But then he has his own moments of agony. A motivational story is one which keeps a balance between its hero's talent and adversaries around him. The struggle must look real which the story does comply with.

The Shawshank Redemption follows Andy Dufresne, a banker accused of the murder of his wife and her lover. In prison, he meets an inmate Ellis "Red" Redding, who Dufresne befriends. Redding is the narrator of the movie talking about his past experience at Shawshank. Over the 19 year period that the movie takes place, Red and Dufresne grow closer, and the tale follows tragic losses of friends, corruption of the prison's staff, and a great escape. This movie is a great movie for those who like a 'justice served' type movie as well as a well written one. In general, foreshadowing indicates that the story is well written enough to the point where the writers can make a reference to the future about what is going to happen. In one scene, Dufresne is carving names into the walls in his cell block. The scene then shifts to Dufresne asking Red if he can acquire a poster (because Red is the guy who can 'get things' in prison). Throughout the entire movie, every scene in Dufresnes cell shows that poster. At the end of the movie it is revealed that the poster hanging on the wall was used to cover a hole that Dufresne had been digging since the night he was carving the names in the wall. He accidentally discovered how flimsy the walls were, and realized he could tunnel out. This makes the movie good because the scenes leading up to the end hinted at the fact that there was something special about the poster, however the audience was never sure. When it was revealed at the end, the audience can make the connection between that night he asked for the poster and the scene where the hole is discovered. Andy Dufresne is accused of murdering his wife and her lover, however it is never actually revealed if he did it or not. The movie goes along hinting that Dufresne is innocent and although it is never confirmed, I found myself trusting the fact that he did not do it. Throughout the movie, Dufresne is treated very poorly, such as being used to launder money for the prison due to his banking background. So when news comes in of a new inmate who confessed to Dufresne crime, Dufresne tries to convince the Warden that he is innocent and demands a retrial or probation. The Warden denies him but at a cost; Dufresne escapes and reveals the corruption at Shawshank causing the Warden to commit suicide to avoid arrest. In general, people who pity Dufresne in his position would feel that he won in the end, escaping the prison and revealing the warden's corruption. This is enjoyable because it has a sense of karma, where because the warden treated Dufresne so poorly, he got fooled in the end. Therefore, this movie is a good movie for people who enjoy social justice type movies, because Dufresne beat the Warden and escaped the prison, as well as for people who enjoy deep movies, that are well written, as demonstrated through the foreshadowing that the writers put into it.

Comment Body: What an enjoyable movie The Shawshank Redemption turned out to be and a true classic. At first glance, the title immediately through me off. It honestly didn't seem like the type of movie I would like. As I got further into the movie however, the storyline began to catch my interest. Andy Dufresne is a well to do banker. He seems intelligent, somewhat corny and well to do. You can imagine my confusion as to how he winds up in prison. Through an interesting plot twist early on in the movie, it seems Andy is falsely accused of a horrendous crime and sentenced to time in prison. Right from the beginning he hits it off with Red, a black older gentleman who seems to be the go to man for everything. Throughout the film Red and Andy develop a loyal friendship that gets them both through the many years of imprisonment. While doing time Andy finds out that there is a way to prove his innocence and is hopeful that he will be released. After expressing that hope to Norton, the warden Andy realizes that he has no intention of helping him and that he would face many more years behind bars. This realization causes Andy to do the unthinkable and Right from the start I felt like the theme was going to be along the lines of hope, never giving up, make the most of your situation or never judge a book by its cover. Andy kept his cool and was hopeful that he would be 'redeemed' throughout most of the movie. You get the sense that he knew he would be proved innocent. He remained hopeful and helpful at all times similar to Pi in Life of Pi. From the beer that he finagled for the prisoners on that hot Summer day, books in the library that he requested and received and the assistance that he provided during tax time, he was definitely more than meets the eye. You honestly don't really expect the ending at all. I didn't really think he'd have that in him. This is a King film though so you know there will be unexpected plot twists.The setting completely made the movie. A drab prison in a remote location, a smelly sewage line and absolutely no grab just sets a tone for unpleasantry, seclusion and discontentment. Considering where Andy came from it was a complete contrast and definitely took some getting used to. Even the transformation of the library - an attempt from Andy in seeking normalcy, was completely realistic in that they took a barren prison room and created shelving, a similar dewey decimal system and structure. The costumes also played an important role within the film and worked hand in hand with the setting. All prisoners wear the same type of clothing and style. There are no stand outs. Some items were more worn than others and some just plain didn't fit well depending on the person. He helped to portray an idea of what it would really be like in prison.Ultimately the movie took a case of misfortune and showed based off circumstances, the lengths that someone would go when the odds are against them. The director also showed us that in the most unlikely places how a true friendship can blossom. Never giving up hope, never judging a book by it's cover.

Keeping this short and sweet, meek Tim Robbins is a convicted accountant who is sent to a real MEAN prison in Maine. The captain of the corrections officers, the massive-jawed Clancy Brown, is quick with his baton, agitato, so to speak. The warden, Bob Gunton, is a corrupt dictator. Morgan Freeman, serving a life sentence, becomes a friend of Robbins. Robbins has a lot in the upper story and goes about doing good for the penitentiary and for the inmates, despite the beatings, attempted rapes, and unjust punishment. Under his management the library becomes a beacon for all prison libraries. Many brutal years pass before Robbins, an amateur geologist, tunnels through the prison wall, hauling a bundle of ill-gotten pelf, crawls into a five-hundred yard long sewer pipe filled with excreta, and splashes through a river to freedom and a tiny coastal village in Mexico, Zijuataneco. I drove there about the time this escape takes place and it really WAS a cheap, peaceful, fishing town with an irregular water supply. Now it's a metropolis. After forty years of imprisonment, Freeman is finally paroled. He joins his friend Robbins in Mexico, where they pursue an honest living as simple fishermen and become lovers for life. (Kidding.) It's a long movie but a gripping one. Movies about prisons are difficult to make. The surroundings are hardly epic, the wardrobe drab, the inmates participate in what the sociologist Erving Goffman called "the small rewards" system common to all total institutions -- gifts and trades of items like cigarettes and harmonicas. The inmates have humble jobs, nothing exciting about working in a laundry. No women. Threats and occasional fist fights but no open warfare. And here there's not even the suspense of watching men prepare for an escape. How do you fold these conditions together and come up with a story? The people who produced "The Shawshank Redemption" have managed to pull it off, and without directorial display -- no fireworks, no instant cutting, no screechy metallic noise on the sound track, no razzle dazzle whatever, just classic movie making. The success of the film is helped ENORMOUSLY by Morgan Freeman's performance as the friend of Robbins. He's an exceptional actor, and though we may see him now mostly in the role of mentor, his early performances as a heavy shouldn't be ignored. God, he was one charming and terrifying pimp in "Street Smart." Robbins does a good job too, although his role requires him to be subdued. It also requires him to be saintly, alas. There's nothing wrong with him. He's a genius, doing everybody's tax returns. He's more sinned against than sinning. Cool Hand Luke at least was reckless and expedient and brought the storm down upon himself. And Luke's guards would have made mincemeat out of Robbins. Robbins' prison is a kind of fantasy land in which he can at will commandeer an office, lock the doors, and play a record of an opera over all the loudspeakers. It's also a pipe dream to believe that all of the inmates would stop what they're doing and stare in wonder at the loudspeakers broadcasting two ladies singing in Italian. Slim Whitman, maybe. But Joan Sutherland? They would have booed. Nor would inmates show the kind of solidarity on display here, once Robbins pulls them together. The coolest presentation of self in an institution like this is utter indifference, except for some offense against the honor of one's self or one's gang. It's a cold-hearted place in which practically nobody applauds when someone else succeeds.However, put all the fantasy aside and accept it for what it is, a fictional tale of men who pay dearly for misdeeds and ultimately save themselves and undermine the foundation of corrupt society. Not heroically, just by sheer persistence.

So, 'The Shawshank Redemption'. Where do I start? The 1994 prison drama based on the Steven King novella 'Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption', from his 1982 collection 'Different Seasons'. Andy Dufresne, a banker from Maine, is convicted for the double murder of his wife and her lover, a crime he did not commit. He is sent to Shawshank State Penitentiary to serve a life sentence. There, he meets Red, a prisoner who smuggles items from the outside world. Andy, who had been an¬†amateur geologist¬†before being jailed, asks Red to get him a rock hammer for shaping rocks he collects from the exercise yard into small sculptures. One of the next items he orders from Red is a large poster of Rita Hayworth. Over the ensuing years, Andy regularly requests more posters from Red, including pin-ups of¬†Marilyn Monroe and¬†Raquel Welch. When asked, Andy tells Red that he likes to imagine he can step through the pictures and be with the actresses. So now you've got a basic overview; let's get into the protagonist and of this fictional prison tale - Andy Dufresnse. As previously stated, Andy is a banker from Maine. At first sight Andy comes across an icy and cold man, whilst in the court room; causing the viewer to lean towards deeming him guilty, rather than innocent. The saying 'Never judge a book by its cover' springs to mind in this instance. We find out Andy is a well educated and extremely crafty gentleman because of his ability to sculpt small rocks with a rock hammer, and his knack for self-education through reading books.A pivotal character in this films plot is Ellis Boyd 'Red' Redding; of whom interestingly - is of Irish heritage; hence the last name 'Redding'. As you may have picked up his nickname is'Red and it is a play on words ofhis last name. He was sent to Shawshank Prison in Maine in 1927, because he planned and carried out his wife's murder by disabling her brakes which accidentally killed a neighbour and child as well, which earned him a life sentence at¬†Shawshank Prison. In the film he is known as the 'guy who can get things' as he regularly smuggles many items into the prison with help from others. Also, a very craft and intelligent man.It is also an incredibly moving story, which makes you ponder what it'd be like to feel as trapped as the prisoners, and to feel the desperation they would have. Not to ruin the plot completely but 'Red' described himself as 'institutionalised', which made him feel like he'd struggle to exist outside the walls of Shawshank. To me, It's a powerful, poignant and thought-provoking film like no other; which truly has the ability to alter your outlook on life, and I believe it could change it in a positive way as it teaches you to be grateful for the life you have, as some others are much worse off than you are. I also admire the attention given to the story, which no other movie that I have watched has quite done. And that is why I consider it as one of my all-time favourites.

Shawshank Redemption is an uplifting, deeply satisfying prison drama with sensitive direction and fine performances. This is an engagingly simple, good-hearted film, with just enough darkness around the edges to give contrast and relief to its glowingly benign view of human nature. Freeman, who is simply a great actor, a man who has never struck a false note in his career, both narrates this tale and anchors it with his authoritative playing. Simply marvelous entertainment. A passing reference to 'The Count of Monte Cristo' offers a partial clue to what makes this movie compelling.Spiritually moving old-fashioned prison picture.

One of the finest films made in recent years. It's a poignant story about hope. Hope gets me. That's what makes a film like this more than a movie. It tells a lesson about life. Those are the films people talk about 50 or even 100 years from you. It's also a story for freedom. Freedom from isolation, from rule, from bigotry and hate. Freeman and Robbins are majestic in their performances. Each learns from the other. Their relationship is strong and you feel that from the first moment they make contact with one another. There is also a wonderful performance from legend James Whitmore as Brooks.He shines when it is his time to go back into the world, only to find that the world grew up so fast he never even got a chance to blink. Stephen King's story is brought to the screen with great elegance and excitement. It is an extraordinary motion that people "will" be talking about in 50 or 100 years.

Comment Head: The "smart" movie for people with simple tastes
Comment Body: This is the film that seems to make people excited that they can tell other film-lovers that they like, because it seems sophisticated. With it's captivating title and the feel-good story of friendship, it's about as complicated as most American movie-goers can get. This can be a decent one to keep on, if you switch to it on TV and have some laundry to fold. However, there are hundreds of films I'd rather watch to stimulate my mind. I would have said thousands but I've only seen slightly over a thousand films so far. I know that many people have a special place for this film in their heart, but they never really seem to stop and ask themselves "why?". Shawshank does have a few, fun gotcha-type moments, and the shot of Andy in the stream after escape is quite memorable. However, the film itself is not one of those birds whose feathers are too bright that "are not meant to be caged." This film needs to stay shelved when we are discussing the greats. It can find itself comfortably and appropriately filed between Shallow Hal and Shiloh.

Comment Head: One of the best endings of all times! Simply wow!
Comment Body: I am at a loss of words to describe the greatness of this film, and by all means I give full credit to the book that it is an adaptation of.Half way through the film I began to enjoy the capabilities of the man and begin to see all that as the point of the film, but then it slows down in pace a bit (for the final "assault") and I end up asking myself the purpose of it all, but then the ending leaves me speechless!This film, alongside the Bollywood biopic 'Manjhi - The Mountain Man' (2015), are two great examples of the fact how time is of little value when there are no better alternatives to achieve your goal. Often in our life we deny to take certain steps which might help us in achieving a goal in some years, but exactly after spending as much time sitting mum, we reflect on the time spent and regret not having taken those steps in all these years.A maternal cousin of mine from Denmark visited us in the summer of 2012 and he mentioned this film in a lot of conversation. Sadly, I wasn't too much into Hollywood films yet. Now that I am since over 15 months I checked the IMDb list of top 250 films and found this on the first place. I was immediately reminded of my cousin and thought that he wasn't after all just randomly naming a film. It was very clever to have shown Andy as innocent. This makes the viewers get more engaged into his suffering in the prison. The scene where he goes to his room with the rope, you almost find yourself saying in heart how this will be great injustice and something very, very sad and depressing.Again, all in all, this film is out of this world. One of the best of all times.

think every generation has their films that they can relate to. My generation related to films like Breakfast Club, Pretty In Pink and Fasstimes at Ridgemont High. Not to say that these films cannot make an impression on today's youth, because I'm sure that they can, but they were definitely films that appealed to kids my age in the 80's. Napolean Dynamite is a film that, in my opinion, is much more of a film that appeals to today's youth. Napolean is a slacker and just wants to be left alone. He has his circle of friends but for the most part, as the poster says, he is out to prove that he has nothing to prove. The film is humorous in some parts, pedestrian in others and overall it is a film that for someone like me ( 33 years old ), it probably doesn't work as well as it does for someone who is in high school. I know many kids that enjoyed this film and most of it was because of Jon Heder. He embodies the very spirit of Napolean Dynamite and even though I found the film to quite average, I have to admit that even I enjoyed Heder's performance. He obviously has a bright future ahead of him with a total of 7 films to his credit in the next two years.

Comment Head: My Brief opinion on a cult classic
Comment Body: One of my favourite films, at first it was shocking, different and I was on the edge of my seat watching what would come around next. With the cast and filmography all working in harmony and the storyline telling a truly human story. The progression of the story from start to finish is brilliant and how the events unfold scene by scene with the heart of the story being about friendship and Hope surviving the most soul crushing situations. To build something in the confines of walls designed to take your life without actually killing you. This still is an amazing piece of cinema and I know that if they try to re make this film in the years to come the original will always be number one.

Comment Head: The best movie of all time

Comment Body: great.....movie nice The Shawshank Redemption is without a doubt one of the most brilliant movies I have ever seen. Similar to The Green Mile in many respects (and better than it in almost all of them), these two movies have shown us that Stephen King is a master not only of horror but also of prose that shakes the soul and moves the heart. The plot is average, but King did great things with it in his novella that are only furthered by the direction, and the acting is so top-rate it's almost scary.Tim Robbins plays Andy Dufrane, wrongly imprisoned for 20 years for the murder of his wife. The story focuses on Andy's relationship with "Red" Redding (Morgan Freeman, in probably his best role) and his attempts to escape from Shawshank. Bob Gunton is positively evil and frightening as Warden Norton, and there are great performances and cameos all around; the most prominent one being Gil Bellows (late as Billy of Ally McBeal) as Tommy, a fellow inmate of Andy's who suffers under the iron will of Norton.If you haven't seen this movie, GO AND RENT IT NOW. You will not be disappointed. It is positively the best movie of the '90's, and one of my Top 3 of all time. This movie is a spectacle to move the mind, soul, and heart. 10/10

Simply amazing and heart touching movie. End of movie is extremely good. Acting I will rate 10/10 to all the cast. Direction 9.5. Story 10. Screenplay 9. Action is not much in movie. Songs I didn't liked. Cameraman 9. Editor 9.5. Story: Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins) is sentenced to two consecutive life terms in prison for the murders of his wife and her lover and is sentenced to a tough prison. However, only Andy knows he didn't commit the crimes. While there, he forms a friendship with Red (Morgan Freeman), experiences brutality of prison life, adapts, helps the warden, etc., all in 19 years.Wrongly convicted, Andy Dufresne (Robbins) is sentenced to two consecutive life terms in in Maine's Shawshank prison for the murders of his wife and her lover.

One of the best movies ever . Great story .Morgan Freeman was great . After opening on 33 screens with take of $727,327, the $25M film fell fast from theatres and finished with a mere $28.3M. The reasons for failure are many. Firstly, the title is a clunker. While iconic to fans today, in 1994, people knew not and cared not what a 'Shawshank' was. On the DVD, Tim Robbins laughs recounting fans congratulating him on "that 'Rickshaw' movie." Marketing-wise, the film's a nightmare, as 'prison drama' is a tough sell to women, and the story of love between two best friends doesn't spell winner to men. Worst of all, the movie is slow as molasses. As Desson Thomson writes for the Washington Post, "it wanders down subplots at every opportunity and ignores an abundance of narrative exit points before settling on its finale." But it is these same weaknesses that make the film so strong.

Christopher Nolan brings yet another adrenaline-filled, comic-inspired movie to the big screen. We see all sorts of familiar faces this time around, but the audience is introduced to a few new characters as well. When crisis threatens Gotham City, Bruce Wayne jumps back into the Batmobile to fight crime. Batman is joined on his quest by an eager orphaned cop (Joseph Gordon-Levitt), a seductive cat burglar (Anne Hathaway), and a violent masked villain (Tom Hardy). This film served as great entertainment with its colorful cast and numerous plot twists. Nolan used actors that had either appeared in previous Batman films or in his blockbuster hit Inception, and all of them shone in their respective roles: Tom Hardy was almost unrecognizable in his Bane costume, while Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Marion Cotillard were both excellent‚Äîand obviously comfortable with Nolan's directing style and the film's dramatic tone.

Comment Head: Proof that box office takings aren't everything.
Comment Body: When I heard that this movie bombed at the box office during its theatrical run, I was very surprised as this is simply an all time classic. Rarely is narration in a movie been done as well as this, Morgan Freeman simply becomes Ellis Redding whose depiction of a hardened con who has accepted that he may never get out and goes through his parole hearings not caring about the outcome. Tim Robbins becomes Andy Dufresne and his portrayal of a man who is really out of his depth and his element, and finding adjusting to life on the inside difficult, almost impossible. The changing relationship between the two characters from initial hostility to deep almost brother like friendship is captivating. Clancy Brown's depiction of the tyrannical Captain Baron Hadley is amazing and likewise Bob Gunton as the hypocritical bible bashing, Warden Norton. The other characters like wise are also well done, especially Brooks and sadistic inmate Boggs. The depiction is what you'd expect from a prison movie and while depicting a life of boring monotony and routine show occasionally punctuated by brief moments of excitement is still fascinating thanks to the soundtrack and of course Morgan Freeman's narration, and I don't want to spoil the ending but it climaxes perfectly with not a dry eye in sight, thanks to the pacing, and the dialogue can't be faulted. Now in regard to the differences from the book, these are for the most part minor and if anything enhance the story rather than hinder it, a rarity. In summary this is a must watch for all movie lovers.

The Shawshank Redemption is a fine and heartwarming tale that holds up after over 20 years. The film is about a man named Andy Dufresne (played by Tim Robbins) who is sentenced to prison after it is ruled he killed his wife. In my mind, The Shawshank Redemption is one of the best "feel good" movies because it is not afraid to present darker themes (suicide, rape, corruption, etc.) and explore the brutality of prison life. But by presenting such a low for the main characters, the audience feels more when the heroes succeed in the end. I feel that Andy is a character most people can empathize, which is critical for a movie of this type. In conclusion, The Shawshank Redemption is a solid film that leaves a good feeling with the viewer, even after the credits roll.

Comment Head: just saw it for the 7th time !!
Comment Body: The story begins with the trial of a young banker, Andy Dufrense, victimized by circumstantial evidence, resulting in a conviction for the murder of his wife and her lover. After a quick conviction, Andy finds himself serving a life sentence at Shawshank prison, with no hope of parole. He exists in this prison only in appearance, keeping his mind free from the drab walls around him. His ability to do this results in the gaining of respect from his fellow inmates, but most of all from Ellis Redding. Ellis, commonly referred to as Red, finds gainful use of his entrepreneurial spirit within the drab walls of Shawshank by dealing in contraband and commodities rare to the confines of prison. Andy's demeanor and undeniable sense of hope causes Red to take a deeper look at himself, and the world around him. Andy proves to Red and the other inmates that in the conventional walls of Shawshank prison convention will find no home in his lifestyle.This film manages to redeem Hollywood in the eyes of people who feared it long lost in a dark sea of clich√©s and predictability. Darabont shows us that artists still work in the Hollywood studios and production facilities. These artists show their capability to produce art; real art that inspires you to look at the deeper aspects of life and the world around you. The Shawshank Redemption delivers much-needed breath of fresh air for anyone who realizes the capability of film. It proves that masters of the craft still live on this earth, and still bless us with timeless masterpieces that we will never forget.

Comment Head: Like the style of this movie very much, and the profound meaning of education.
Comment Body: The shaw shank redemption is undoubtedly a good film, no movement, no special effects, even no beauty, but still can impress the audience, and after more than ten years and charm. It depend on what attracted us? Some say because it reflects the toughness of the "human nature". Indeed, with a small hammer, nearly 20 years, the personal control is very strict fascist prison, unearthed a small escape tunnel (perhaps call hew to knock a small tunnel is more suitable, the hammer is too small). But I think the plot is dramatic obviously, this is just a director in the arrangement of the plot, at the end of this just in order to reflect the "self-salvation" Andy finally succeeded, otherwise the whole plot and theme. Such as Andy escaped prison after letter to Rhetta said: "Remember, Hope is a good thing, maybe the best of things and no good thing (dies." Maybe that's what works and director want to tell us. "Fear can hold you prisoner, Hope can set you free." This sentence has become a famous. To me, "the shaw shank redemption" touched my place not only on this. Tell me about my ideas about the characters in the film first. A shark fort prison, the prisoners inside and officials, seems to be that our society. High above the warden NORTON, at ordinary times, on the lines, such as the bible actually gain by hook or by crook, cruel and cunning and greed. Guards long Haley and other officers, and vicious brutality, ACTS as NORTON's thugs, grass Jan the prisoner's life. They are like a power class in our reality? I call it a shark fort ruler of the "small society". There are different in the prisoners. Besides the protagonist Andy, Rhetta (Morgan Freeman) is a key figure, of course, I think he is a clue of the film: in fact, the whole movie dialogue is not much, in the film a lot of want to show the things is by Rhetta monologue, which were mostly Rhetta to shaw shank life reflection to summarize and his interpretation of Andy. Rhett is a wise man, and he in shark fort mix very well, make the demand of people he was less than "no". His wisdom and insight into the shark fort the essence of life, he said to Andy: "the shark fort, hope is a dangerous thing", this is the wise man's tongue. In my environment, people will say "Rhetta comrade very sophisticated," at such a time. However, and the reality of the so-called "wise men", although Rhetta see see through the essence of the shark fort, but he didn't want to fight in the past, not to mention influence and change others, he is only conform to the rules in order to protect themselves in the shaw shank. Until Andy appear, changed his, and eventually lead him to the freedom of the other shore.

According to me this movie is one of the best movies i have ever come across till my 21st birthday,till date. It is one of the remarkable works in direction,acting and arts. Peace. :)

A great film to watch anytime because it moves you every time you watch as it depicts friendship, hope and redemption. The friendship between the characters Andy and Red is amazing. Would have won Oscar if it wouldn't have been made in the year 1994. Comment Head: Breathtaking Prison movie! one of my best
Comment Body: Im not going to write a massive review as so many people have already told you everything you need to know about this amazing film.I will however say 3 things that make it my favourite film.1, I have yet to find a film that matches this for inspiring Hope, Dreams and Friendship.2, Shawshank Redemption is Stephen King at his best.3, Even if you don't usually like prison films this one will be the exception.These three points are the reason why Shawshank Redemption is my comfort blanket and will always be my go to film..

HOPE!-A very powerful word that incites sense of faith is the main theme of the movie. That coupled with friendship gives us this amazing movie which is just too good to watch. There's a reason why it has been at the very top since decades.It's because it touches the human part of you. Frank Darabont did an excellent justice to this movie.There is nary a word or scene out of place in the entire thing.It's an adaptation of Stephen King's novel. The characters are brilliantly cast.Andy Dufresne, played by Tim Robbins, has been sent to prison for a crime he did not commit. But he never loses hope. He never gives up his quest to become a free man again. There's a part of you which wants to see him accomplish this.The story focuses on Andy's relationship with "Red" Redding (Morgan Freeman, in probably his best role) and his attempts to escape from Shawshank and the stories that unfold with that quest. If you haven't seen this movie until now, go watch it,you won't be disappointed.

This movie is a must watch movie. I bet everyone loved this movie for sure. Acting is superb.The Shawshank Redemption" is a movie about time, patience and loyalty not sexy qualities, perhaps, but they grow on you during the subterranean progress of this story, which is about how two men serving life sentences in prison become friends and find a way to fight off despair.The Shawshank Redemption" is not a depressing story, although I may have made it sound that way. There is a lot of life and humor in it, and warmth in the friendship that builds up between Andy and Red. There is even excitement and suspense, although not when we expect it. But mostly the film is an allegory about holding onto a sense of personal worth, despite everything. If the film is perhaps a little slow in its middle passages, maybe that is part of the idea, too, to give us a sense of the leaden passage of time, before the glory of the final redemption.

Comment Head: Great film based on a classic novel.
Comment Body: Directed by Frank Darabont, this film ticks all the boxes of what excellent films are all about. It encompasses the reality of a prison thriving on corruption among its operators as Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), the protagonist, struggles to serve a sentence wrongfully imposed on him. It seems the only thing helping him survive the harsh reality of prison is fellow inmate Red (Morgan Freeman) with whom he forms a special friendship. Life for Andy in a tough prison is set to last him all his life. If you're looking for a movie that will take you on an emotional roller coaster, or a tear-jerker, then this is the film for you. Great cast, excellent story-line and perfect acting. It's based on the novel written by renowned author Stephen King. So get your tissue boxes out and ice-cream because this movie is emotionally draining. Great film, 9/10. Really.

Comment Head: One of the best movie that i watched.
Comment Body: This movie is watching worthwhile. You cannot just predict about whats going on. Really fascinating movie. Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman was outstanding. It's like I was present with them all the way. The way this movie was started and till the very end it was marvelous. I have to mansion about the dialogues used in this movie that they were truly inspiring. This movie made me think about life. Surely it can inspire ones life and can lead to greatness. Yes, it was one of the best movie that i have ever seen. Direction was quite well and cast were more then perfect. The character for Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman suits them most and I think no one can do better then them :)

Comment Head: The best and most realistic drama film i've seen in ages.
Best Prison Movies of all time

Comment Body: This film adaption of Steven King's short story is a masterpiece. It's one of those movies that I am compelled to watch every time it's on TV, and that's often. Andy finds himself in prison for a murdering his cheating wife, a crime he did not commit. Some of the prisoners place bets on his chances of survival right away. But they soon find out that Andy is tougher than he appears. In the darkest of places, Andy's light finds a way to shine. He will not allow his human spirit to be imprisoned. The corrupt warden exploits Andy's financial knowledge and has Andy help him to extort money and hide it. Andy helps him, but grudgingly. At the end of the movies the viewer is delighted by Andy's ingenious escape as he makes his way through hundreds of yards of muck only to waltz out of town with all of the warden's money. Andy's friendship with Red adds to the touching story, as Red, upon his release, makes his way to his friend Andy as he lives out his life in the beauty of a Mexican beach.This story is timeless and beautiful. Tim Robins and Morgan Freeman play their parts perfectly. This movie has so many amazing moments that it's impossible list them all. This is a must-see movie.

I think this has been one of the finest movies ever made. I thought cinema in all it grandeur. Frank Darabont needs to be applauded for his direction. You can judge the finesse of the director by the perfection he shows to capture the smallest details in a movie. All the actors involved from small to lead roles have done a tremendous job in their portrayal. The film is riveting and gripping. It does require you to be patient as the build up of the characters takes some time. but once the story moves forward it captures you and you are mesmerized by the story and it builds a connection. I have watched this movie couple of times and can surely say that you will watch again its just that sort of a movie. This one is a must watch.

Comment Head: What can I say about this life changing , gathering and extraordinary movie?
Comment Body: The first time I watched this movie everything was dark and unsolved for me because I didn't get the main message of the movie, the message that Frank Darabont was trying to extend between us "Humans".So I watched it ten more times and that was when I realised My life has been changed.Even that I knew every single dialogue from the movie and all I did was to liken the movie to my life. likening prison , likening the people and likening the freedom. Now I will just write 10 words so that next time you're watching the movie , you will focus more on it. Prison , Enemies , Music , Thinking Aloud , Hope , Hope , Hope , Hope , Hope and Hope. The first thing that I will show my children is The Shawshank Redemption before any shitty pipe animations and cartoons.Thank you Hamed/2015

Comment Head: One of the Top 100 Movies of All time
Comment Body: No matter what I'm doing, if Shawshank Redemption is on; I have to drop everything and watch it. It's one of those films that grabs hold of you and never let's you go and will haunt you long after the credits role. The entire cast was superb lead by Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman. Their friendship chemistry on screen was palpable, rich and sweet. Beautiful to watch. And let's not forget the wonderful adaptation from Stephen King's short story. Frank Darabont is a filmmaker I respect and admire and he gets it right were other King filmmakers sadly fail. If you have not seen it, do yourself a favor and watch it as soon as possible. You will not soon forget it.

The Shawshank Redemptionabsolutely amazing movie its a must see if u haven't seen it already i could not take my eyes away from the screen i was scared to go to toilet in case i missed anything Morgan freeman played his part to perfection as did Tim Robbins i would recommend anyone to watch this if they have not done already hard to believe this was 1994. a simple prison movie based on hope, friendship and redemption. a fantastic movie that touches the soul of so many people. if (and that is a big if) you do not like this movie then i will be absolutely shocked and surprised. i have rated it a ten out of ten because i think this movie is by far one of the best i have watched to date (2015).So people watch it take in every second of the movie and most of all ENJOY!!!!!!

Comment Head: A classic piece of unforgettable film-making.

Comment Body: Im not going to write a massive review as so many people have already told you everything you need to know about this amazing film.I will however say 3 things that make it my favourite film.1, I have yet to find a film that matches this for inspiring Hope, Dreams and Friendship.2, Shawshank Redemption is Stephen King at his best.3, Even if you don't usually like prison films this one will be the exception.These three points are the reason why Shawshank Redemption is my comfort blanket and will always be my go to film

I first watched it when I was 10 years old, and my mind immediately discarded it, but once I started to watch films for what they represent, I can honestly say that this film has all the qualities a great film will have: Great screen writing, great actors, a great director, a captivating story and a plot that swings you towards a great end.This film represents what the whole film industry now a days has at times forgotten: You don't have to make a saga of films for people to remember your work, all you need is a great story that, despite being so complex, explains itself during the whole film, and doesn't need to be 3 or 4 hours long for you to understand the characters or empathize with the situations.All in all this film will forever be the perfect example of how any film should be made, in order for it to be remembered.

This movie has the one thing every great movie has, and that is that the movie is tied together and all the details conform into one great story at the end. Don't get me wrong the movie was great through every scene (especially small details, like how Red sees 'Brooks was here' carved into the ceiling of the room Brooks hangs himself in), but the moment you think you'll see Andy hanging lifeless from his cell you find out that he has escaped Shawshank. In the next moments while watching you start to realize that from the first day Andy talked to Red about the pick hammer, he already has his plan in mind. And even though it seems as if Andy wants the poster of the actress while watching the film for his own pleasure, he actually used it to cover up the tunnel he dug during the years he was in Shawshank. Andy's calm demeanor when under pressure from the warden and the guards causes him to slip under their eye and dig the tunnel to escape Shawshank. That's why this is my favorite movie of all time, because the conclusion makes you realize things that were going on throughout the story that no other movie ending can even come close to how the Shawshank Redemption ends.

Comment Head: A masterpiece! Nothing else to say...
Comment Body: I have to thank to the director, actors, screen players and the other people who made this film. -Morgan Freeman is a genius of the cinematography and stars only in very beautiful pictures. -Tim Robins plays one of the most loved characters ever. -Frank Darabont made his best film. -The storyline is one of the most interesting that I've ever seen. One of my favorite movies ever! I'm happy that this film is in top 10 but i consider that there are other films who deserve to be no. 1, but I still love this picture! I hope next generations will love this film the same way I do. Continue to make gorgeous pictures! Best wishes! B-)
